DataElement.preferredDefinition: The name of the regional (spinal/epidural) anesthesia agent applied to a restricted area or part of the body prior to organ removal in order to produce a loss of feeling.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A drug or other substance that causes a loss of feeling or awareness. Local anesthetics cause a loss of feeling in one small area of the body. Regional anesthetics cause a loss of feeling in a part of the body, such as an arm or leg. General anesthetics cause a loss of feeling and a complete loss of awareness that feels like a very deep sleep._Of or belonging to a broader area or region of the body._The act of the dispensing, applying, or tendering of something to another, such as administration of a medicine.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: (an-es-THET-iks) Substances that cause loss of feeling or awareness. Local anesthetics cause loss of feeling in a part of the body. General anesthetics put the person to sleep.

Concepts.definition: A pharmacological agent that acts in a reversible fashion and can be applied either locally or systemically to cause a partial or total loss of sensation and pain or to induce unconsciousness.

Property.preferredDefinition: Of or belonging to a broader area or region of the body.:The act of the dispensing, applying, or tendering of something to another, such as administration of a medicine.

Concepts.definition: Of or belonging to a broader area or region of the body.
The act of the dispensing, applying, or tendering of something to another, such as administration of a medicine.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: A category of organic or inorganic substances, elements, and isotopes used in research or for the prevention, diagnosis, and/or treatment of disease states. Includes biologically active substances that are either synthetically manufactured or endogenous substances extracted and processed to be reintroduced into an organism. Chemicals and drugs also include hazardous substances, and naturally occurring or synthetically produced substances required to maintain life.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The words or language units by which a thing is known.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 1/25/23 added alt name for ticket number CADSR0001948 for CCTG cjl.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A synthetic aminoethylamide with local anesthetic and antiarrhythmic properties. Lidocaine stabilizes the neuronal membrane by binding to and inhibiting voltage-gated sodium channels, thereby inhibiting the ionic fluxes required for the initiation and conduction of impulses and effecting local anesthesia.

Concepts.definition: A synthetic aminoethylamide with local anesthetic and antiarrhythmic properties. Lidocaine stabilizes the neuronal membrane by binding to and inhibiting voltage-gated sodium channels, thereby inhibiting the ionic fluxes required for the initiation and conduction of impulses and effecting local anesthesia.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An amide-type, long-acting local anesthetic. Bupivicaine reversibly binds to specific sodium ion channels in the neuronal membrane, resulting in a decrease in the voltage-dependent membrane permeability to sodium ions and membrane stabilization; inhibition of depolarization and nerve impulse conduction; and a reversible loss of sensation.

Concepts.definition: An amide-type, long-acting local anesthetic. Bupivicaine reversibly binds to specific sodium ion channels in the neuronal membrane, resulting in a decrease in the voltage-dependent membrane permeability to sodium ions and membrane stabilization; inhibition of depolarization and nerve impulse conduction; and a reversible loss of sensation.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: A category of organic or inorganic substances, elements, and isotopes used in research or for the prevention, diagnosis, and/or treatment of disease states. Includes biologically active substances that are either synthetically manufactured or endogenous substances extracted and processed to be reintroduced into an organism. Chemicals and drugs also include hazardous substances, and naturally occurring or synthetically produced substances required to maintain life.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The words or language units by which a thing is known.

Concepts.definition: The words or language units by which a thing is known.
